DOC.HEAD: Agent Orange Benefits Checks Mailed
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 8,900 supplemental benefit checks totalling $27.3 million were mailed last week to Vietnam War veterans disabled by the chemical defoliant Agent Orange, the lawyer administering the payment program said Monday. During the next several days 500 more checks will be sent to veterans or their survivors, said the attorney, Deborah Greenspan. The payments ranged from $256 to $8,100, she said. U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Brooklyn, who is overseeing the Agent Orange benefit program, last month ordered that the additional payments be sent before Christmas. The payments won't significantly change the total award an eligible veteran will receive, but will provide a large share of the compensation in a lump-sum payment. Veterans receiving the supplemental checks will continue to receive annual benefit payments until 1994, but the amount of the yearly payments will be reduced somewhat to account for the lump-sum payment. Weinstein created the Agent Orange Settlement Fund in 1984 when seven chemical companies _ without admitting guilt _ agreed to pay $180 million to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by Vietnam veterans and their families who alleged injuries because of exposure to the chemical during the war. Agent Orange, widely used by American forces during the Vietnam War, contained the highly toxic chemical dioxin. In their lawsuit, veterans said exposure to the defoliant caused cancer and other illnesses, as well as birth defects in their children.
